revisions.*:
'''George "Wild Child" Butler''' (October 1, 1936 – March 1, 2005) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[guitarist]], [[harmonica]] player, and [[singing|vocalist]].

Butler was born in [[Hernando, Mississippi|Hernando]], [[Mississippi]],<ref name="AMG"/> or [[Autaugaville, Alabama|Autuagaville]], [[Alabama]], [[United States]],<ref name="Acoustic"/> and began playing blues music in bands from the late 1950s, but it was not until 1966 that he began to receive notice, after moving to [[Chicago]] and signing with [[Jewel Records]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 97–98
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> His early sessions were recorded with [[Willie Dixon]], [[Cash McCall (musician)|Cash McCall]] and [[Jimmy Dawkins]] as sidemen.<ref name="AMG">Bill Dahl, [{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p298/biography|pure_url=yes}} George "Wild Child" Butler] at [[Allmusic]]</ref><ref name="russell"/> He recorded an album for [[Mercury Records]] in 1969.<ref name="russell"/>

In 1981, Butler moved to [[Ontario]], [[Canada]], where he played regularly.<ref name="AMG"/> In the 1990s, he began [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] with [[record producer]] [[Mike Vernon (producer)|Mike Vernon]] in [[England]], which resulted in two albums released on Bullseye Blues.<ref name="AMG"/>

Butler died on March 1, 2005 in [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]], Ontario, of a [[pulmonary embolism]], at the age of 68.<ref name="Acoustic">[http://news.acousticsounds.com/index.cfm?sector=news&page=read&newsid=15 Acousticsounds.com - accessed June 2009]</ref>

==Discography==
*''Open Up Baby'' ([[Jewel Records|Jewel]]/[[Charly Records|Charly]], 1966)
*''Keep On Doing What You're Doing'' ([[Mercury Records]], 1969)
*''Funky Butt Lover'' ([[TK Records]], 1976; reissued as ''Lickin' Gravy'' on [[Rooster Blues]])
*''These Mean Old Blues'' (Bullseye Blues, 1992)
*''Stranger'' (Bullseye, 1994)
*''The Devil Made Me Do It'' ([[Ace Records (United States)|Ace Records]], 1999)
*''Sho' Nuff'' (APO Records, 2001)
